data.title: Crash when checking options in Project Settings
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** Ubuntu 16.10, Clang 3.8.1 - Godot Git, compiled from commit https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commit/681575fa7123592897090c6cce44402c4e45baeb

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

Godot will crash when checking options in the Project Settings. It occasionally happens, not 100% of the time.

**Steps to reproduce:** Check some options in the Project Settings, eventually it will crash. GDB reports this as "exiting normally" though, so it doesn't seem to be possible to get a backtrace.

data.title: Option for detaching script from node (#6934).
data.body: Fixes #6934

data.title: Add option 'wasm' to compile to WebAssembly in web export
data.body:
e.g. `scons p=javascript wasm=yes`

WebAssembly is experimental, so disabled by default.
The standard is still in flux, so the compile toolchain is occasionally broken.
Compiling for WebAssembly requires the `incoming`-branch of Emscripten.
Running WebAssembly requires nightly browser builds with WebAssembly flag enabled.

If `LLVM_ROOT` in `~/.emscripten` is set to Emscripten's "fastcomp" fork of clang, Godot will be compiled per `asm2wasm` (i.e. first compile to asm.js as usual, then translate that to wasm). This method of compilation currently has better chances of finishing successfully.
If `LLVM_ROOT` points to clang built with experimental WebAssembly backend (`-DLLVM_EXPERIMENTAL_TARGETS_TO_BUILD=WebAssembly`), the output will be translated per `s2wasm` to WebAssembly. This method should eventually offer better performance.

The HTML shell file now uses `$GODOT_BASE`, a placeholder for the base filename, instead of `$GODOT_JS`, `$GODOT_MEM` and `$GODOT_FS`.

data.title: Remove JavaScript compilation option 'compress'.
data.body:
This functionality has been removed from Emscripten in version 1.36.13,
server-side compression is recommended instead.

data.title: IPv6 support for ENet networking module
data.body:
Now that we have IPv6 support in the engine, we need to extend the ENet module to support it too in the `NetworkedMultiplayerEnet` API.

AFAIK upstream ENet has no IPv6 support, and there is still no sign upstream of willing to add it. There are two pending PRs adding it (not reviewed):
- https://github.com/lsalzman/enet/pull/21 (needs rebased)
- https://github.com/lsalzman/enet/pull/51 (merges cleanly, recently rebased)

As IPv6 support is a growing concern and ENet is quite popular, I imagine that there might be many forks out there that add the feature. We should try to find one which is well maintained, and use it as a replacement to our upstream ENet - hacking it ourselves would be a waste of time (unless there are really no good forks implementing it).

In this issue, we should thus list all forks/branches we can find and try to assess them. Then we could try to get in touch with those developers and see if they'd be up for making their repo an alternative upstream that can be used by Godot (and maybe eventually packaged in Linux distros as new enet version if the lsalzman/enet repo continues ignoring PRs).

data.title: Use IPv6 dual stack socket by default. Allow restricting IP version for TCP/UDP.
data.body:
In this PR:
- TCP_Server and PacketPeerUDP now listens by default using Dual Stack sockets (supporting both IPv4 and IPv6)
- StreamPeerTCP and PacketPeerUDP connect/set_send_address now allow you to select which type of IP you desire from hostname resolution.
- Calling TCP_Server and PacketPeerUDP `listen` with ip_type `IP_TYPE_IPV6` will create an IPv6 only socket.
- Update the docs.

This patch closes #6951 and closes #6933 .

There are still some minor things I'd like to ask:
- @akien-mga can you have a look at the updated docs and check if it's ok?
- @reduz , sorry to disturb you, I wanted to bind the enum `IP_Address::AddrType` to the IP class at least when exported, but IP_Address needs it and IP includes ip_address.h. Is there a way to tell the Object Database to bind that particular enum to another object (structs/base types do no allow)? Right now punto had them registering on the base type `int` like `int.IP_TYPE_IPV6`, `int.IP_TYPE_ANY`, and so on, which I think it's a bit confusing.

EDIT: Also closes #4651

data.title: Coding standards: Python files
data.body:
As a monolithic issue (#3916) does not make it easy to discuss specific points, let's split some topics in their own issue (always referencing the main one) so that we can progress forwards.

---

We have various Python files in the source, mostly related to the buildsystem or some helper scripts.

I'd propose to follow the Python standard for those, PEP 8: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/
The main disruptive change of PEP 8 for us would be that it enforces space indentation (:innocent:), while we currently have a stronger tendency to use tabs (though it's not done consistently and we have a lot of mixed situations).

Since most auto-formatting tools enforce spaces, I'd propose to use that convention too for our Python files (not C++ of course, where we should stick to our _de facto_ tabs standard).

Alternatively, we can decide to use PEP 8 and tabs for indentation, we just need to tweak the PEP 8 checking tools to disable some warnings and errors related to indentation. One advantage of keeping tabs is that we're consistent with the C++ code, so we don't have issues with conflicting IDE configs.

data.title: Globals.localize_path fails to localize an absolute path
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Regression from #6813

`Globals.localize_path(String path)` is returning the same absolute path that was passed to it, instead of the localized path.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Example with the Platformer 2D demo:

``` GDScript
func reproduce_the_bug_plz():
    var local_path = "res://player.gd"
    var global_path = Globals.globalize_path(local_path)
    assert(local_path == Globals.localize_path(global_path))
    #assert(global_path != Globals.localize_path(global_path))
```

data.title: Fix 2 search menus are shown
[Documentation] Expose math types default constructors
data.body:
- Vector2
- Vector3
- Matrix32
- Matrix3
- Quaternion
- Color
- Transform
- ...

Primitive math types often have multiple constructors, but the default one is not listed. Also, some people read the docs first before writing code (especially with a scripting API), it can be misleading to hint there is no default constructor, leading them to not even try.

These constructors exist, they can be used. But if they are not found by doctool... then we have another problem, because not a single default constructor is ever documented, not just math primitives. Which leads me to think they are bound automatically, and unavailable to doctool.

Original request: https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/6752#issuecomment-257141732

data.title: Fix bug with saving last select language and remove warning
Directory.list_dir_begin( ) returns the wrong value
Broken UI and bunch of error messages in console
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10, Godot Alpha 2.2 (October 29th- 30th)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
After building latest Godot and running it, the UI seems to be broken. 

The issue appears right away in the Project Manager: vertical slider of the project list is located in the middle of the list container, even though it should be aligned to the side.

Next, scene tree simply doesn't work. The slider is aligned ok, however when I do scrolling the content doesn't scroll, just the scrollbar. When I select item, it is being selected in the 2d editor, however there is no indication in the scene tree. 
Also two buttons overlap in the scene tree panel-> button with the plus icon and with a script icon.

Inspector is broken as well- the same as with the scene tree: there is no indication that something is being selected, some icons seems to be using hi-dpi and some low-dpi icon sets, however the scrolling is working.

Other panels(Node, File System) are simply just messed up, everything is overlapping and it's impossible to make sense of anything there. 

Also, after opening the project, the editor freezes for some time and when it gets back responsive, I noticed there are lots of error messages in the console; here are a couple of them:
failed method: TextureProgress:_update_callback target ID: 1640

> failed method: TextureProgress:_update_callback target ID: 1640
> TOTAL BYTES: 1048572
> NULL count: 8
> CALL : 87206
> CALL _update_callback: 52
> CALL _sort_children: 17
> CALL _update_minimum_size: 18
> ERROR: MessageQueue::push_call: Condition ' (buffer_end+room_needed) >= buffer_size ' is true. returned: ERR_OUT_OF_MEMORY
> 
> failed method: HBoxContainer:_sort_children target ID: 1671
> TOTAL BYTES: 1048572
> NULL count: 8
> CALL : 87215
> CALL _update_callback: 45
> CALL _sort_children: 15
> CALL _update_minimum_size: 18
> ERROR: MessageQueue::push_call: Condition ' (buffer_end+room_needed) >= buffer_size ' is true. returned: ERR_OUT_OF_MEMORY

Basically it's the same error on and on just for the different nodes. 

**Steps to reproduce:**
Simply build the latest Godot alpha v2.2 and run it

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

data.title: Travis: Those ever timing-out Android builds
data.body:
Android builds on Travis are often timing out for no good reason - mainly it seems like the download of the SDK/NDK takes too long and Travis kills the build.

@bojidar-bg tried a workaround in #6738 but it did not work out.

We need to find a fix, or disable the android target, as it's getting tiring that half the PRs are shown as not passing CI because of a timeout on a single job (and I've checked, there's no option in GitHub to not show erroring jobs as broken, contrarily to Travis itself which makes a distinction between errors (!) and failures (x)).

We could also try moving the android builds to the container-based Linux infra instead of the more limited OSX nodes - then the main question is whether we can get the SDK and NDK easily.

data.title: RigidBody2D is missing set_collision_layer func
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.1

I'm messing around with rigid bodies with 2d platforming and collision layers/masks. Looks like calling:

rigidbody.set_collision_layer(0) 

returns

`Invalid call. Nonexistent function 'set_collision_layer' in base 'RigidBody2D (player.gd)'.`

Collision layer does work for `RigidBody2D` as well because if you change it from the inspector, it works as intended :D

data.title: Core: Register TriangleMesh type
data.body: The type is [passed as parameter](http://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/classes/class_editorspatialgizmo.html#class-editorspatialgizmo-add-collision-triangles) of `EditorSpatialGizmo.add_collision_triangles()` but the type is not registered. @reduz mentioned the type was going to be moved out of core or something. I don't remember but assigning him.

data.title: Add a Polygon2D equivalent in 3D
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux, current master branch

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
As far as I know, there is no option to simply "mask" a Sprite3D like in 2D with a Polygon2D to prevent alpha overdraw (Does this even exist in 3D? [I've no idea of 3D :-)]).
I think the only option right now is to import a polygon mesh and add a texture to it. But this is not very convenient if you have to add 100+ Sprites.
